data.title: Minnesota native Steve Zahn scores big with a role in HBO’s ‘Treme’
data.meta_description: The first time we see Steve Zahn’s character in “Treme,” he’s under the spell of music.The compelling and highly anticipated new HBO drama takes place in New Orleans three months after Hurricane Katrina and Zahn has just gotten out of bed when he hears the unmistakable sounds of a brass band. He throws on some […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

The first time we see Steve Zahn’s character in “Treme,” he’s under the spell of music.

The compelling and highly anticipated new HBO drama takes place in New Orleans three months after Hurricane Katrina and Zahn has just gotten out of bed when he hears the unmistakable sounds of a brass band. He throws on some clothes, bolts out the door and follows the music. It’s the first second line (a neighborhood street parade) since Katrina devastated the city, and for Zahn’s character, Davis McAlary, it triggers a flood of emotion — excitement, hope, possibility.

As a DJ and musician, McAlary is an eccentric who’s as smart as he is stubborn. With a teetering chip on his shoulder, his passion for the New Orleans music scene is matched by contempt for authority. Based on real-life New Orleans musician Davis Rogan, who served as a consultant on the show, Zahn’s McAlary is so completely believable, you would think he has some history with the city, but that’s not the case.

Zahn, a Minnesota native who grew up in Mankato, spent a few weeks in New Orleans two decades ago while performing in a touring Broadway show. That was the extent of his relationship with the city until “Treme,” which is named after Faubourg Treme, the New Orleans neighborhood where jazz was born.

“I fish and go duck hunting,” said Zahn, 42, who lives on a farm in Kentucky with his wife, Robyn, and two kids, Henry and Audrey. “I’m completely opposite from my character, although I loved the music to begin with and have grown to love it even more since I’ve been here.

“I think sometimes it’s better to come from a different world as an actor,” continued Zahn, who plays guitar and mastered a few licks on the piano for the show. “You have a different perspective than if you were really into it. Someone coming in to play a guy from Minnesota, maybe I wouldn’t do it as good as an actor from Texas who sees things differently than I do — the things that I might take for granted.”

For Zahn, joining the ensemble cast of “Treme” was an easy decision. He’s a fan of the show’s creators — David Simon, of the critically-acclaimed HBO series “The Wire,” and Eric Overmyer, a veteran writer and producer whose credits include “Law & Order,” “The Wire” and “Homicide: Life on the Street.”

“They’re brilliant,” says Zahn. “They write story well and they write dialogue well and they understand character.”

As far as characters go, it’s a strong lineup. Along with Zahn’s spacy McAlary, there’s a Mardi Gras Indian (Clarke Peters) coming back to the city he loves despite protests from his children, a trombonist (Wendell Pierce) trying to get a gig anywhere he can to make ends meet, a struggling restaurant owner (Jeanette Desautel), a bar owner (Khandi Alexander) searching for her brother who hasn’t been seen since Katrina, a zealous college professor (John Goodman) with a short fuse and an attorney (Melissa Leo) trying to help find the bar owner’s brother.

Throughout “Treme’s” 80-minute pilot, Simon and Overmyer create a world that feels desperate and hopeful at the same time. John Boutte’s uplifting “Treme Song” provides the soundtrack for the opening credits filled with images of walls caked in mold. Much of “Treme” is like that: the exuberant sound of music — trumpets, trombones, pianos and percussion — offering a support system for folks struggling to get their lives back together after the levees failed.

The authenticity of “Treme” is partly due to Simon and Overmyer’s decision to use many locals in the show, including musicians Kermit Ruffins, Dr. John, Allen Toussaint and members of the Rebirth Jazz Band.

“Every once in a while, somebody would drive by and scream out their sunroof, ‘Go back to Hollywood.’ And everybody on set looks around at each other and says, ‘Is there anybody here from Hollywood? Everybody lives here. This is a New Orleans show,’ ” says Zahn. “Now, it’s just a question of other people watching it outside the city.”

Coming on the heels of “The Wire,” Simon’s gritty, absorbing look at the guts of Baltimore through the eyes of drug dealers, politicians and cops, “Treme” has a lot of hype to live up to. Zahn thinks it can handle the pressure:

” ‘The Wire’ was brilliant, but again, it’s the same guys with the same voices who deal with their subject matter in the same sensitive way,” says Zahn. ” ‘Treme’ will be as good as ‘The Wire’ and maybe more accessible because of the music. New Orleans is a place everybody knows about and has an opinion about even if they haven’t been here.”

Amy Carlson Gustafson can be reached at 651-228-5561.

What: “Treme,” new series about post-Katrina life in New Orleans by David Simon and Eric Overmyer featuring Minnesota native Steve Zahn

When: 9 p.m. Sunday

Where: HBO

GOING TO NEW ORLEANS?

Here are Steve Zahn’s recommended stops to hear music next time you’re in the Big Easy.

d.b.a: “If you’re going to go out down here and have a good time and see music, you want to go to Frenchman Street. Go to d.b.a — there’s never a bad band in there.”

The Maple Leaf Bar: “To go see the Rebirth Brass Band play at the Maple Leaf is one of the 10 things you should do in your life.”

Vaughan’s Lounge: “You have to go see Kermit Ruffins play Thursday night at Vaughn’s.”

Bullet’s: “It’s a great place to go see music.”

Originally Published: April 8, 2010 at 11:01 p.m.
